text: there have been a number of interesting
technical trends at this World Cup and
one of them is the general absence of
two man striking teams
Edinson Cavani and luis suarez of
uruguay constitute probably the only
pure team of two strikers in the
tournament while 442 has made something
of a comeback from its heyday as the
standard tactic in football well back
into the 2000s this is largely as a
defensive measure the 442 allows to
compact banks of four for defense as
shown by Iceland Burnley or Atletico
Madrid and gives good coverage of the
whole pitch however many of these four
four 2s are more like four four one ones
with one genuine striker and a shadow
striker or attacking midfielder playing
off them increases impressing and the
fitness of teams meant that withdrawing
a second striker to more of a play
making role makes sense because it
increases a team's defensive solidity
this means that while the low block
looks like there are two men playing up
top only one of them is a genuine
striker the other player is there to
provide a creative transition from the
low block to carry the ball into wide
areas on the counter and look for the
genuine striker and fill back in
midfield if required other 442 s such as
that used by Roy Hodgson at Crystal
Palace or Senegal under Luc say defend
as a 442 but use players who are not
classic strikers in the front two roles
Hodgson used Wilfried Zaha and Andres
Townsend while CC dropped main bærum
Diouf himself more of a defensive
forward who chases and presses and
creates room for others in favor of and
by ngayon playing up front alongside
Sally Imani Niang is most regularly used
as a winger in Torinos for three three
or four two three one while marnai is a
wide forward in Liverpool's 433 this
means that the two strikers and the two
white players have greater positional
fluidity while they defend as a 442 the
players skill set means that they can
drop off break wide and swap in with
wide players that can attack from deep
to confuse opposition markers of course
many teams only use one striker
anyway the 4-2-3-1 is still very popular
even if its limitations against low
blocks have been exposed at this World
Cup as has its reliance on really good
energetic and tactically aware defensive
midfielders in the double-pivot 4-2-3-1
gives teams a variety of
attacking options and only requires one
striker who can hold the ball up and
bring others in or in the case of Timo
Bernhard Germany run beyond the
playmaker the three playing behind are
there to create and cut inside and so
while they get into striking positions
generally speaking they're not strikers
there is the odd exception like Mario
Mandzukic playing wider Aventis but
these are rare and don't generally
imitate the two man striking team this
system is supposed to give greater
defensive solidity to as the attacking
three can fall back into a four four one
one or a 4-5-1 easily these same
considerations apply to a lot of
three-man defensive line teams the three
four three uses one striker and two
white players 3-5-2 can have two pure
strikers but generally tends to see at
least one dropping off to play more as
an attacking midfielder a good example
of this is England's fluid 3-5-2 which
effectively sees one pure striker Harry
Kane playing with Raheem Sterling who
drifts wide or drops off ahead of the
two attack-minded midfielders the aim is
to create space through movement or to
create overloads between the lines to
allow quick exchanges and putting
players through on goal this movement as
well as the defensive considerations of
more players who can drop off is the key
to why two strikers tend not to be
selected much attacking play now
consists of this creation of movement
and space and two strikers can be too
static similar players don't tend to
work so well together and are more
easily marked by the center backs the
old pairing of one large striker to win
the knock downs for a smaller poacher is
now redundant when pressing can cut down
on crossing and physically strong quick
center backs can mark players so well
teams now try to attack by working in
the spaces between the lines hence the
idea of a false-9 striker dropping off
an allowing movement from inside
forwards towards the goal and attacking
midfielders getting into the box beyond
one main striker given all that the
reason that Uruguay have persisted
successfully with Cavani and Suarez is
largely down to their qualities and
their extraordinary work rate as well as
that of the midfield of place behind
them óscar tabárez system requires both
strikers to track back and press and
they do this brilliantly the work of
Lucas Herrera and the rest of the
Uruguayan midfield also means that they
can still play with solidity and leave
at least one of the two strikers free
for count
but players like this are rare it's
little wonder that both Suarez and
Cavani have over 100 caps and both play
elsewhere in systems that require them
to drop off and create space as well as
X as a lone focal striker is rare to
have two strikers that can also fit into
this and that's why Uruguay are the
exception at this World Cup and not the
norm
one football is the app for you there's

information fixture lists and all the
rest take a look at the link in the

watching
